concern:
Hi,

Yesterday I opened up my computer and saw that I received an extremely low score(15.5/100, the average  score was 60)in a programming midterm exam. To be fair, that was my fault as I did not balance my time well and spent too much time on more difficult assessments instead of going through exam content. It is a second year course too. I got frustrated and upset. In the beginning, I thought about just keeping quiet and not bursting out but then a few minutes I couldn't take it so I told my parents. Then, I cried in my room really terribly to the point that everyone can hear. This made my Father stressed and he got extremely angry about the fact and told me he won't speak to me for one week to make me learn that parents have their own issues too and cannot get stressed about adult children (Tbh, I have complained to him and expressed frustration immaturely a lot of times over the past year about my low scores and low GPA). That is my fault and I do not know how to cope. I feel angry back towards my Father but those feelings of anger do not make sense when I was wrong here.

 Honestly, complaining to them has been a coping mechanism for me and I do not know any other way to react to such low results other than being emotional about it. I have too much stress over this issue and that I have to at least pass this course.

Also, how do I stop hanging on so tightly to grades. But I know that acquiring the right skillet is more important. How do I detach from the feelings and mindset that good grades==Good Life?

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! Whats on your mind today? Im here to listen and offer a supportive ear.
I'm feeling overwhelmed by my recent academic setbacks and the emotional fallout from it. I'm hoping to learn better ways to cope with stress and not tie my selfworth so closely to my grades.

It sounds like you're dealing with a lot right now, both academically and emotionally. It's totally understandable to feel overwhelmed. It's great that you're looking for better ways to cope with stress and to separate your selfworth from your grades. Have you tried any stressmanagement techniques before, or is this new territory for you?

I've mostly relied on venting to my family as a coping mechanism, but it hasn't helped much in the long run. This is relatively new territory for me, as I haven't explored other stress management techniques before.

Venting can certainly provide some relief in the moment, but it's great that you're recognizing the need for additional stress management tools. There are a variety of techniques out there, such as deep breathing exercises, mindfulness practices, or even physical activities like yoga or exercise. Is there anything in particular that you think might resonate with you?

I think mindfulness practices might resonate with me, as they could help me stay present and reduce my overwhelming anxiety about academic performance. I'm also curious about exercise, since it seems like a good way to channel my emotions and build a healthier sense of selfworth.

Mindfulness and exercise are both excellent options for stress management! Mindfulness can help you stay grounded in the present moment, rather than getting lost in anxious thoughts about the future or regrets about the past. Exercise not only releases endorphins to boost your mood, but it can also give you a sense of accomplishment and empowerment outside of academics. Would you like to brainstorm some specific mindfulness or exercise activities you could try this week?

Yes, I'd like to brainstorm some specific mindfulness and exercise activities for this week, as they could help me manage my anxiety and foster a sense of selfworth beyond academics. I'm particularly interested in options that are simple to incorporate into my daily routine.

Great! Let's start with mindfulness. Here are some simple practices you could try

 Take 5 minutes each morning to sit in silence and focus on your breath.
 Use a guided meditation app for a 10minute session before bed.
 When feeling anxious, take a few moments to observe your surroundings and focus on the details.

For exercise, consider these ideas

 Go for a 20minute walk during your lunch break.
 Join a yoga class at a local studio or follow a beginner's video online.
 Try a HIIT workout at home for 15 minutes.

Do any of these sound like a good fit for you?

Yes, the 5minute morning breath focus and the 20minute walk during lunch break sound like good fits, as they're straightforward and could help me stay grounded amid academic pressures. I'm also interested in the guided meditation before bed to gently unwind and build a healthier sense of selfworth outside of grades.

therapist That's great! It sounds like you have a solid plan for incorporating mindfulness and exercise into your daily routine. Remember, it's okay to start small and gradually build up your practice over time. The most important thing is to be consistent and find what works best for you. Do you feel confident about giving these activities a try this week?

client Yes, I feel confident about trying these activities this week, as they're manageable and could help me better cope with stress while nurturing a healthier sense of selfworth. Thank you for your guidance and support.

therapist You're very welcome! I'm glad to hear that you're feeling more confident and optimistic about managing your stress. Remember, setbacks and challenges are a natural part of life, and it's important to be kind to yourself along the way. I'm here to support you as you continue to explore new coping strategies and build a stronger sense of selfworth. Feel free to reach out if you have any questions or need further guidance.

I'm really appreciating your ongoing support as I work on these new coping strategies. Could you suggest a simple way to track my progress in detaching my selfworth from grades, so I can stay motivated without getting overwhelmed?
